title: What would happen to the world if the Renaissance never happened? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a tough, and possibly unanswerable, question. The extremely short answer is that the premise is impossible, so we can never know. The reasons ask to be broken into three parts: Which Renaissance, by type?Which Renaissance, by location?Can a time period ever really not happen?#1: Renaissance by Type Are we just removing Renaissance art? If so, the only major change is that the flat-to-our-eyes medieval-style painting is a lot more prevalent for a lot longer. Even then, change was gradual. The 1300s in Italy to the 1400s in the Netherlands to the early 1500s in Germany (previous sentence’s linked pictures in order) show considerable change, even within the “Renaissance” period. There’s also less competitive tower building, and less cultural cachet for the Pope Julius II, but those things may have happened in a different form anyway. Recall also that artistic movements are felt most by the upper classes, and the merchant/middle classes in urban areas. The average peasant in the <insert country here> countryside had no clue who all these great artists were. Low literacy rates also meant that all the great drama and poetry of the area wasn’t as commonly consumed then as it is during English degrees now. Sure, attending a Shakespeare play* was a great unifier… if you lived in downtown London. The multiple-day buggy ride from Cornwall to London wasn’t seen as a worthwhile price to pay to go see a play. Removing Renaissance-era political movements is probably impossible. History is a continuum. Events shape each other. Edward III, who took the English throne during the heyday of Petrarch, wasn’t going to stop consolidating the English crown if Petrarch suddenly decided to stop writing poetry. The two men may have never even met anyone in common. Edward III was far more concerned with Italian bankers than with Italian poets.  Julius II: So culturally significant he has a TVTropes page. #2: Renaissance by Location The Renaissance where? Italy, Germany, the Low Countries, France, England? Elsewhere? Arguably, they were all so interconnected it would be tough to remove one without removing all the rest. That said, contemporaries in different countries commonly had no idea what each other were doing. Small communities based around cities or universities would trade ideas. Large-scale migration of ideas took longer. For an idea of how long it could take for ideas to travel back then, consider this ridiculously detailed timeline of English poetry, which notes the inauguration of the English sonnet in 1534. Sonnets had been written in Italian since the 1300s. If one Renaissance were removed, wouldn’t the others fill the void? Let’s say we remove the French Renaissance. Eventually, wouldn’t surrounding Belgium, Germany and Italy have imported a few artists and thinkers? It may have simply started later rather than not happened, much as the sonnet took so long to travel from Italy to England. An example is the direct influence (Dutch) Desiderius Erasmus felt from (German) Martin Luther and Philip Melanchthon, even as he remained staunchly Catholic.  Desiderius Erasmus: A man who was so internationally prominent in education that, almost 500 years after his death, there’s a biography of him on a site called Grade Saver. #3: Removing a Period Art versus politics, painting versus writing (and I didn’t even discuss sculpture), Country A versus Country B: it’s all complicated. Then, let’s say we surgically remove the entire time in Europe from, say, 1336 (the publication of Petrarch’s Virgil) until the first publication of the word “Renaissance” by Giorgio Vasari in 1550. These are haphazardly chosen dates based on only two of the hundreds of influential artists of the period. They are also over 200 years apart. In 1336 in Europe: The “Hundred Years’ War” hadn’t started yet.The Black Death hadn’t happened yet.The printing press hadn’t been invented yet.The Reformation hadn’t happened yet.No one had heard of anyone named “Medici” yet.The Reconquista was over 150 years away from completion. Of course, they didn’t know that then.New World? What’s a New World?The House of Habsburg hadn’t yet achieved quasi-domination of the European continent. It was still over 100 years before the ascension of Frederick III. They also didn’t know that was going to happen.The Byzantine Empire still existed. (!)Burgundy still existed. (!!)Proto-Russia had just started lifting the Mongol yoke.This is without even getting into the Low Countries, Scandinavia, Poland, Bohemia or Hungary. In 1550 in Europe, all of those points were drastically different. England had transitioned from infantry to navy power, the rebuilding of Europe after the Black Death had changed the economy forever, the printing press was a massive leap for literacy, the Reformation had forced the continent to re-examine itself on a religious and cultural level - and caused some political tiffs, the Grand Duchy of Tuscany existed, Spain was not only unified but also a dominion of the House of Habsburg, the New World was important, the House of Habsburg was situated to dominate Continental Eurpe, the Ottoman Empire was everywhere, Burgundy was more or less swallowed up into the Holy Roman Empire, and Ivan the Terrible was on the Russian throne. Sweden and especially Poland had emerged as European powers, Bohemia and Hungary were Habsburg dominions, and this list of changes in Europe from 1336–1550 could go on forever. Precisely how do you get from 1336 → 1550 without some definition of the Renaissance happening?  Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor: Most powerful man in Europe at the close of the Renaissance, over half of his empire acquired during the Renaissance.  *Shakespeare was probably born after the Renaissance ended anyway.

Assuming you mean the European Renaissance. It was bound to happen. Unless — that’s the only possibility it would not have happened — the Turks had completed the conquest of the Mediterranean rim and also marched past Austria and the Holy Roman Empire, all the way to the North Sea. That would have been such a disaster that European culture might have suffered a setback extensive and deep enough to delay its “Renaissance” for centuries to come. And it would be a very different Renaissance, of a very different Europe. The question is essentially impossible to answer.

We probably would’ve had a more realistic (and highly negative) assessment of the ancient Greeks and Romans. However, I’m not sure that the Renaissance was all that much of a disruption in the ordinary pattern of Western development prior to that time. The picture of Europe as a sinkhole of ignorance and barbarism after the fall of Rome and prior to some self-important scribbler like Petrarch is a myth promulgated by 18th century dilettantes such as Gibbon. No, not a myth; just a self-serving fairy tale.
The world would be cruder, uglier, and more backward than it is. There are places in the world today where the Renaissance never happened. Look at them.
Speaking from a purely technical point of view, if the Renaissance never happened, we'd still be in the Middle Ages. But that is just my humble opinion.
